resources.description: Project Proposal for Map Plant Communities & Influence of Annual Water Table Fluctuations on Successional Expression: Malheur NWR

name: map-plant-communities-influence-of-annual-water-table-fluctuations-on-successional-express
notes: The 2012 Malheur NWR CCP identified the development of an ecological succession model (State-and-Transition Model, or STM) as a high priority for understanding how management actions influence habitat expression within the Refuge’s 20,000+ acres of wet/dry meadows. The 2012 information collected in the plant community mapping project funded by the Region 1 I&M Program provides the foundation for development of the STM. The Ecology Work Group1 identified that defining and documenting the interactions between the existing plant communities and hydrology is the next critical step in development of the STM. This will require mapping and linking the hydrologic gradients and plant assemblages. Soil moisture data will be collected within the 2012 I&M study area.This information will provide the Refuge and its partners (e.g. Ecology Work Group) test and increase the predictive ability of the model in understanding habitat management implications and vegetative trends resulting from climate change and human manipulation of hydrology. This proposal has two components: 1) add +75 more plots in targeted areas of last years study area to better define the vegetative expression of each acre, and 2) construct 10 water table wells equipped with hobos to track seasonal changes in depth/duration of soil moisture within each community type.Objective 1: Use 2012 I&M-project data as a the baseline to capture plant communitytypes on a per-acre basis. At minimum of 80 additional plots will be established in thesouthern Blitzen Valley (south of Krumbo Lane). This is a critical next step identified bythe Ecology Work Group that will enhance the ability to identify necessary managementactions and hydrogic manipulations to slow or reverse negative trends in the plantassembalages and habitat quality of the Refuge’s wet/dry meadow habitat type.Objective 2: Monitor change in depth/duration of soil moisture across hydrologicalgradients and correlate water table characteristics with plant community change andwater management.Objective 3: Utilize scientific expertise within the Ecology Work Group to incorporatevegetation plot and well data into the Malheur NWR State-and-Transition Model.
title: Map Plant Communities & Influence of Annual Water Table Fluctuations on Successional Expression: Malheur NWR
